headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Regions Financial Corporation's Quarterly Earnings Call. My name is Paula, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. List Underwood to begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Regions Financial Corporation's Quarterly Earnings Call. My name is Paula, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. List Underwood to begin.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. We appreciate your participation in our call today. Our presenters are Grayson Hall, our Chief Executive Officer; and David Turner, our Chief Financial Officer. Other members of management are present as we
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. We appreciate your participation in our call today. Our presenters are Grayson Hall, our Chief Executive Officer; and David Turner, our Chief Financial Officer. Other members of management are present as well and available to answer questions as appropriate.
Also as part of our earnings call, we will be referencing a slide presentation that is available under the Investor Relations section of regions.com.
Also, let me remind you that in the call, and potentially in the Q&A that follows, we may make forward-looking statements, which reflect our current views with respect to future events and financial performance. For further details, please reference our forward-looking disclaimer that is located in the Appendix section of the presentation.
With that said, I'll turn it over now to Grayson.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you, List. I want to say just a few words about List Underwood before we get started with our financial results. As we announced earlier this week, List will be retiring at the end of the month. He's been with Regions for 23 years
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you, List. I want to say just a few words about List Underwood before we get started with our financial results. As we announced earlier this week, List will be retiring at the end of the month. He's been with Regions for 23 years and has been a trusted adviser and valued member of our management team. His impressive career spans 43 years and today marks this 90th earnings call with our company.
List, congratulations. We'll certainly miss you as you start a new phase in life and wish you the very best in retirement.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Grayson.
componenttext: Thank you, Grayson.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on to results. Overall, we're pleased and encouraged by achievements and results in 2015. During the year, we focused on the fundamentals: growing and deepening our customer relationships and also strengthening our financial performance by investin
componenttext:
Moving on to results. Overall, we're pleased and encouraged by achievements and results in 2015. During the year, we focused on the fundamentals: growing and deepening our customer relationships and also strengthening our financial performance by investing in initiatives that will drive revenue growth and create a more efficient and effective organization in the future. As a result, we're a much stronger organization today and are committed to continuing to build sustainable franchise value. For the fourth quarter, we reported earnings from continuing operations of $272 million, bringing our full year 2015 total to $1 billion.
Earnings per share for the quarter totaled $0.21 per diluted share and $0.76 per diluted share for the full year. These results reflect growth in total adjusted revenue despite the challenging operating environment. Importantly, we continue to deliver results in categories that we believe are fundamental to future income growth, including checking accounts, households, Regions360 relationships and credit card accounts. For example, checking accounts grew by more than 2% during the year, and active credit cards increased 11%. We remain focused on expanding and deepening relationships through our need-based approach to relationship banking, and our 2015 results demonstrate that this approach is working.
During the year, we delivered strong average deposit growth of $3 billion or 4%. The mix of our deposits continues to strengthen as 92% are now low-cost deposits. As we have noted before, our markets provide us with a unique and competitive advantages from a deposit composition perspective.
In 2015, we achieved solid adjust loan growth of $5 billion or 6% from the prior year. Adjusted loans and leases include a lease reclassification adjustments, which David will speak to you shortly. Both business and consumer grew loans with total production for the year of $66 billion or an increase of 12% from 2014. Business lending had an excellent year growing adjusted loans 7%. Commercial banking, corporate banking, all grew loans. And 95% of our markets achieved loan growth, reflecting strength of our business model collaborate with industry and product specialists to grow loans. In particular, within corporate banking, our specialized industries grew experienced solid growth led by technology and defense as well as franchise restaurant, and the real estate investment trust lending business was strong throughout the year. Consumer Lending was also strong in 2015. Total loans exceeded $30 billion at year end, an increase of 5% over 2014. Mortgage led this growth with loans increasing $496 million or 4%. Additionally, our new initiative bolstered growth in indirect lending with increased loans of $339 million. Additionally, credit card balances increased 7% from the previous year, which drove growth in card and ATM income of $30 million or 9%. Total adjusted revenue for the year increased 2% over 2014, reflecting growth in the balance sheet and investments we made to grow and diversify our revenue. Capital markets income was exceptionally strong, increasing $31 million. Our recent acquisition of Block Arch Partners as well as our planned initiatives are expected to further augment capital markets income in the future. Wealth Management had a strong year with income increasing 10% over the prior year. Our focus to grow Wealth Management by continuing to retain, improve and develop talent was evident in the success of our financial consultants and insurance initiatives. During 2015, we executed on our capital plan, returning 93% of earnings to shareholders, which is expected to be the highest percentages among our peers. We also made several small yet important investments and acquisitions in 2015 that will help drive future income. These transactions were prudent and optimal use of our capital enabling us to expand our capabilities and product offerings to supplement future revenue growth.
With respect to the economic environment, while the U.S. economy is still slow and steadily improving, there is a clear significant pressure from the global economy. Low oil prices continue to create challenges for certain industries while benefiting others. Consequently, we continue to closely monitor our energy portfolio. As expected, there continues to be downward migration in risk ratings in this portfolio. These shifts will continue if oil prices remain at current levels. However, we remain in close contact with our energy customers and believe it, we're taking appropriate actions to mitigate We continue to prudently build reserves, which now stand at 6% of our direct energy exposure. As a result, we are cautious but we expect the future losses related to this portfolio to be managed. As we began 2016, we remain committed to our 3 primary strategic initiatives: first, grow and diversify our revenue streams; secondarily, to practice disciplined expense management; and lastly, to affect capital. These are all integral to successful execution of our strategic plans. We continue to operate in a challenging environment, and that requires us to focus on what we can control. To that end, as we discussed in our Investor Day in November last year, it is essential to take more aggressive steps as it relates to expense management. Our goal is to eliminate $300 million of core expenses over the next 3 years, approximately 9% of the 2015 adjusted expense base. This plan, which is underway, will help us kind of growth initiatives and bring sustainable franchise value. In summary, 2015 was a solid year for Regions. We accomplished a great deal while laying the foundation of future earnings growth.
With that, I'll now turn over to David who will cover the details for the fourth quarter. David?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. I'll take you through the fourth quarter details and then provide our expectations for 2016. As Grayson noted, 2015 was a solid year for Regions, and the year-end was particularly strong sets us well -- sets us up we
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone. I'll take you through the fourth quarter details and then provide our expectations for 2016. As Grayson noted, 2015 was a solid year for Regions, and the year-end was particularly strong sets us well -- sets us up well for 2016. Before I get started, during the fourth quarter Regions corrected the accounting for certain leases, which had previously been included in loans. These leases had been classified as capital leases but were subsequently determined to be operating leases. The cumulative effects on pretax income, lower net interest income and other financing income, $15 million and reduced the net interest margin by 5 basis points in the quarter. The adjustment resulted in a reclassification of these leases out of loans into other earnings assets totaling approximately $834  million at the end of the quarter. The company does not expect this adjustment to have a material impact to net interest income or other financing income or net interest margin in any future reporting period.
With respect to balance sheet, adjusted loan and lease balances totaled $82 billion at the end of the fourth quarter and were up $1 billion or 1% from the previous quarter. Business lending achieved solid growth with adjusted balances totaling $52 billion at quarter end, an increase of 1%. Adjusted commercial loans grew $563 million or 1%. Commitments increased 2%, and utilization increased 30 basis points to 46.3%.
Consumer Lending had another strong quarter with every loan category increasing. Loans in this portfolio totaled $30 billion, an increase of 1% over the prior quarter. Indirect auto lending increased 2% and other indirect lending, which includes point-of-sale initiatives, increased $55 million linked quarter or 11%. We are pleased with the results of this initiative. Year-to-date, loans in this portfolio have increased $339 million, and we expect continued growth in 2016.
Looking at the credit card portfolio, balances increased 6% from the previous quarter, and our penetration rate into our deposit base now stands at 17.3%. up 160 basis points from the fourth quarter of last year.
Mortgage loan balances increased $81 million, and total home equity balances increased $31 million from the previous quarter as new production continued to outpace portfolio runoffs.
Let's take a look at deposits. Average deposit balances increased $322 million, and ending balances increased over $1.2 billion during this quarter. Deposit costs remain at historically low levels at 11 basis points, and total funding costs remained low at 26 basis points. With respect to deposits, we are primarily core deposit-funded with 74% of our deposits coming from consumer and wealth deposits. Low-cost deposits were 92% of total deposits. Approximately half of our deposits come from cities with less than 1 million people, and 50% of our deposits are from customers with $250,000 or less in their account. This is why we believe our deposit base will be a competitive advantage for us as rates rise.
Let's look at how this impacted our results. Net interest income and other financing income on a fully taxable basis was $856 million, essentially flat with last quarter. However, excluding the impact of the lease adjustment, net interest income and other financing income increased $15 million or 2%. Higher loan balances and balance sheet hedging and optimization strategies were the primary drivers behind the linked-quarter increase along with interest recoveries. The benefit from interest recoveries is not expected to be at this level in the first quarter, approximately $4 million less going forward. The overall increase in net interest income and other financing income was partially offset by fixed asset repricing.
The net interest margin was 3.08%. Now we're excluding the lease adjustment, net interest margin was 3.13% or flat with the previous quarter.
Total noninterest income increased 4% on an adjusted basis from the third quarter, driven primarily by gains on sale of affordable housing investments and by higher card and ATM income. Card and ATM fees increased 3%, primarily related to an increase in commercial bank card usage and increase in the number of active cards of 3.7% and an increase in seasonal consumer spending. Service charges were impacted by posting changes that went into effect in early November and reduced noninterest income by approximately $7 million. We expect the ongoing impact of this change to be at the lower end of our previously stated $10 million to $15 million quarterly range. Wealth Management income was down slightly quarter-over-quarter due to lower insurance income, partially offset by higher investment management and trust fee income.
Capital markets income was relatively flat linked quarter as revenue from new product and service offerings was offset primarily by lower loan syndication fees. 
Let's move on to expenses. Total reported expenses in the fourth quarter were $873 million. On an adjusted basis, expenses totaled $861 million, representing a decline of $33 million or 4% from the prior quarter. This included a decrease of $24 million in FDIC fees, primarily due to additional expenses of $23 million in the third quarter related to prior assessments. The expected quarterly run rate for this expense in the $22 million to $24 million range excluding the impact of the proposed FDIC surcharge. Additionally, the fourth quarter benefited from lower expenses related to unfunded commitment cost of $12 million. Salaries and benefits increased $8 million or 2% linked quarter, primarily attributable to $6 million in the severance-related expenses. We also incurred $6 million of expenses related to 29 branch consolidations. Our adjusted efficiency ratio was 63.4% in the fourth quarter, but excluding the $15 million lease adjustment, the adjusted efficiency ratio was 62.7%.
As discussed at Investor Day, we will continue to make investments to grow our business. However, we must be more efficient in everything we do. As Grayson noted, our plan to become a more efficient organization, including the elimination of $300 million in business is underway.
Let's move on to asset quality. Total net charge-offs increased $18 million to $78 million and represented 38 basis points of average loans. This increase was primarily related to 1 large charge-off in the Energy loan portfolio. Total Business Services criticized and classified loans increased $117 million, driven by some weakening in a small number of larger loans, primarily within the Energy portfolio. However, total nonaccrual loans excluding loans held for sale declined from the third quarter. Total debt restructured loans or TDRs also declined, down 1% from the prior quarter. The provision for loan losses was $69 million, and our allowance for loan losses was down 2 basis points to 1.36% at the end of the fourth quarter. And at quarter end, our loan loss allowance to nonaccrual loans or coverage ratio was 141%. Regarding our Energy portfolio although prices have declined, exposure remains manageable. Should oil prices remain at current levels, charge-offs will be in the $50 million to $75 million range in 2016. The Energy charge-off taken this quarter reduces the previous range of $50 million to $100 million. Additionally, we have currently have just over $150 million reserved or 6% of our direct energy exposure. And given where we are in the credit cycle, the volatility in certain credit metrics can be expected, especially related to larger dollar commercial credits in our portfolio and fluctuating commodity prices.
Let's move on to capital and liquidity.
During 2015, we returned $925 million to shareholders, which included the repurchase of $621 million of common stock and $304 million in dividends. Under Basel III, the Tier 1 ratio was estimated in 11.7%, and the common equity Tier 1 ratio was estimated at 10.9%. On a fully phased-in basis, common equity Tier 1 was estimated at 10.7%, well above current regulatory minimums.
Our loan and deposit ratio at the end of the quarter was 83%. And at the end of the quarter, we were fully compliant as it relates to the liquidity coverage ratio.
Now let me give you an overview of our current expectations for 2016. We expect total loan growth to be in the 3% to 5% range and an average basis excluding the impact of the operating lease reclassification. And regarding deposits, we expect full year average deposit growth in the 2% to 4% range. And commensurate with our loan growth projections, we expect net interest income and other financing income to increase in the 2% to 4% range. Now should we experience no additional rate increases, we expect to be at the lower end of that range. As a result of our investments, we expect to grow adjusted noninterest income somewhere in the 4% to 6% range. Now we will continue to make investments in 2016, however, we have also begun to execute our plan to eliminate $300 million of core expenses, of which 35% to 45% will occur in 2016. Therefore, we expect total adjusted noninterest expenses in 2016 to be flat to up modestly from 2015.
We expect to achieve an efficiency ratio of less than 63% in 2016 and positive operating leverage somewhere in the 2% to 4% range. Now we still expect our net charge-offs to be in the 25 to 35 basis point range. However, given the current price of oil, we would expect to be at a top end of that range. In closing, the fourth quarter was a strong finish to a solid year. The investments we made in 2015 positions us well for 2016 and beyond, and we look forward to updating you on the progress throughout the year as we continue to build sustainable franchise value.
With that, we thank you for your time and attention this morning. I will now turn it back over to List for instructions on the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ryan Nash of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe we'll just start off on credit. First, can you maybe give us a little more color on the loss you took, what type of loan was it? Is there any credit left? And then I guess when you think about as a reserve that you've taken, the roughly 6%, what is
componenttext: Maybe we'll just start off on credit. First, can you maybe give us a little more color on the loss you took, what type of loan was it? Is there any credit left? And then I guess when you think about as a reserve that you've taken, the roughly 6%, what is your reserve contemplate for oil prices? And you've heard others so that if oil prices stayed at this level you could see a net income in the amount of provision. Just wondering what that number would be for you.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Barb Godin, Ryan. Let me go ahead now to the question, and I'll address the second part. The first part was an energy credit that sit around for the few years M&A activity, which originally led to the credit. It is a Shared National Credit. There are
componenttext: It's Barb Godin, Ryan. Let me go ahead now to the question, and I'll address the second part. The first part was an energy credit that sit around for the few years M&A activity, which originally led to the credit. It is a Shared National Credit. There are 5 banks involved, and we saw some distress in this credit in the early part of the year, so we have been working this credit really hard during the course of the year. And it simply came to conclusion near the end of the year. And what we've done is we have appropriately marked that credit. We've taken the loss in that credit, as you've heard, and we've moved the residual balance into the held for sale, and we anticipate that we will have that our held for sale numbers by the end of -- we're hoping January, but certainly this quarter, it will be out of our numbers. And back to individual credits, the charge-off on that approximately $25 million, just for rounding. In terms of how we think about our reserve and look at prices as we work our way through our process, in the backs of our minds, if we look at our price deck, our price deck is roughly $36 right now sensitivity, $28.90, so we're looking in that range as we determine and establish what those numbers should be, but we're also looking very heavily at each and every individual customer, what their cash flow looks like what our collateral looks like, what our asset coverage is, we currently have asset coverage of 1.71x and business, for example. So again in conversations that we have ongoing conversations with our customers because we really do have a small number of customers, we still believe that repayments ability is adequate with them and again, establish our reserves accordingly.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then David commented in his prepared remarks that you're expecting charge-offs to be towards the high end of the 25 to 35. I guess from both a portfolio whether it's metals and mining or some other related areas or even if it's across differen
componenttext: Got it. And then David commented in his prepared remarks that you're expecting charge-offs to be towards the high end of the 25 to 35. I guess from both a portfolio whether it's metals and mining or some other related areas or even if it's across different geographies whether it's Texas or Louisiana or anywhere else that's exposed to oil and gas, are you seeing any other changing in credit patterns fixup in delinquencies or anything that has an impact on either growth or the overall credit performance?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We're keeping a really close eye on all of that. There is some pressure, certainly, on commodities in general across the industry as you know, and that's just given that the strong U.S. dollar what's going on in Europe and in China in terms of the dis
componenttext: No. We're keeping a really close eye on all of that. There is some pressure, certainly, on commodities in general across the industry as you know, and that's just given that the strong U.S. dollar what's going on in Europe and in China in terms of the dislocation of the market, so there is some pressure there, but we've seen nothing yet that is significantly concerning.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Maybe just one last quick one, David. Can you just help us understand the trajectory of the net interest margin? It may be both the forward curve and if we don't get any additional rate where do you think the NIM would trend over the course of
componenttext: All right. Maybe just one last quick one, David. Can you just help us understand the trajectory of the net interest margin? It may be both the forward curve and if we don't get any additional rate where do you think the NIM would trend over the course of the year?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ryan, give a little bit of guidance if we don't get another change, we'll be at the lower end of our 2% to 4% guidance that we've given you. I also gave you a little bit of guidance from our prepared comments in terms of margin. We did have unusual r
componenttext: Yes, Ryan, give a little bit of guidance if we don't get another change, we'll be at the lower end of our 2% to 4% guidance that we've given you. I also gave you a little bit of guidance from our prepared comments in terms of margin. We did have unusual recovery, interest recoveries. We think about $4 million that won't repeat going forward, but we're looking for a relatively stable NIM, and this is adjusting by the way, for lease accounting. So we were at 3 0 8 on net interest margin, 5 points related to lease adjustments. So 3 13 would have made us flat, and we're looking for a relatively stable. And just to remind everybody that's been 1 or 2 points either side of where we are for 2016. And so we're looking for that guidance in terms of growth and NII that we really been focusing on to be that 2% to 4% through the year, so you may see some unusual changes in a given quarter, but you got to keep the year in mind when thinking about NIIs or trajectory.

componenttext: Maybe following up on Energy, when I look at the -- you guys added some disclosure on the criticized loans, which I think was pretty interesting and when you look at that, you're actually higher as a percentage basis in that E&P portfolio compared to services, so I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing that more comfortable with the exposures on the E&P side and, I guess, maybe a little bit less though on the oilfield services.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I get it's Barb Godin. I'd be happy to answer that. As we do our redeterminations, and we just finished our full year [ph] determination just about then, what happens is as you readjust the borrowing base -- and again, for full year [ph] determinations th
componenttext: I get it's Barb Godin. I'd be happy to answer that. As we do our redeterminations, and we just finished our full year [ph] determination just about then, what happens is as you readjust the borrowing base -- and again, for full year [ph] determinations this year, borrowing base adjustments downwards were a little under 8%, notwithstanding if that cost us over advanced what you would immediately do is call that loan a criticized loan and move it into a non-task category. So again, that would account for the reason that we have roughly 48% of our E&P book that is showing right now as criticized. Having said that, we have a rigorous process as well around our oilfield services portfolio. As you can see on the chart that we did provide, 32 customers make up 75% of that portfolio, so we're able to stay in constant and close contact with them. Again, as we see any weakness in there, again, we are very quick to move into a criticized category.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: Just maybe to follow up on that, on the E&P portfolio, if you have 400 -- if close to half of the loans were in -- a lot of those were in an over advanced position I would think they'd will he be in a further over advanced position now that where oil prices have gone since the redetermination was fleet So would that suggest that real criticized exposure might even be higher than that?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The spring redetermination we did, that was somewhere between roughly 15% reduction in borrowing basis, and now we're saying that there's an incremental 8% so round it up on top of that, so roughly 23% reduction in borrowing base. Remember as well in
componenttext: No. The spring redetermination we did, that was somewhere between roughly 15% reduction in borrowing basis, and now we're saying that there's an incremental 8% so round it up on top of that, so roughly 23% reduction in borrowing base. Remember as well in the industry customers get a a 6-month cure period in which they're able to cure and we have seen that number of customers. Again, those earlier in the year that had access to capital markets and even now those that are still very strong have access to capital markets and were able to take themselves out of an overadvanced position.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just as we think about the dislocation we're seeing in the markets right now, now it's fairly early what you guys have any sense of how that if this continues how that would impact the strategy guys have for growing the market in the Wealth Management business? Is there anything that's sensitive to market activity levels? And would you be more concerned about the growth trajectory?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll tell you that we're creating these new products and services. The driver of that is because our customers need that, and we're looking to have more offerings to our customers, and we're out there talking to dumb we feel very good about
componenttext: This is David. I'll tell you that we're creating these new products and services. The driver of that is because our customers need that, and we're looking to have more offerings to our customers, and we're out there talking to dumb we feel very good about where they stand right now, which is why we reiterated our guidance for 2016 on things like loan growth being 3% to 4%. We're seeing in our discussions with our customers, we still see the domestic economy being okay. We're looking at 2%, 2.5% GDP. And so there is the dislocation that's happening here of late, but as we see our customers, we believe they need to products and services, the capital markets investments we make we think are going to be very strong and looking for that to continue and help us get to that 4% to 6% growth rate that we're expecting in noninterest revenue.

componenttext: It's actually Steve Moss for John. I guess, first off for List, congratulations, and good luck on your retirement here.  And wanted to ask about Energy again. Just wondering here with regard to oil if it declines further to $20, $25, let's say, what are your potential losses there?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we look at and I'll ask Barb to reiterate and complete the statement, but we look at our Energy portfolio, we have got a very disciplined process of calculating probability to falls and laws. Given the falls got the redetermination supper doing o
componenttext: Well, as we look at and I'll ask Barb to reiterate and complete the statement, but we look at our Energy portfolio, we have got a very disciplined process of calculating probability to falls and laws. Given the falls got the redetermination supper doing on the E&P portfolio twice a year, and so we feel good about the level of rigor and discipline around our process that drives that evaluation of how much we reserve based on what we think the incurred losses may be. And so, I think that our confidence in that process is very solid. We're staying disciplined around to that process. And if oil prices continue to decline, that process is going to drive risk ratings down on some of our credits and will drive a higher level of criticized lettuce classified loans, and we will drive how we reserve against those loans it will be incurred loss basis and until that incurred loss occurs from accounting perspective, our process is going to determine it. So Barb?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what I would add to that is the operative word here being how long the oil price will stay depressed. And you mentioned somewhere in the $20 a barrel range. And again if the $20 a barrel range stays there for an entire year, it could be in terms o
componenttext: I think what I would add to that is the operative word here being how long the oil price will stay depressed. And you mentioned somewhere in the $20 a barrel range. And again if the $20 a barrel range stays there for an entire year, it could be in terms of charge-offs, this is not provision, it could be up to an incremental $50 million. And that is based on some back of the envelope versus anything precise I would have to tell you. But again, that's our view and I don't think it's the view of the industry at this point that oil is going to stay sub-$30 for any length of time.

componenttext: No, we're feeling very good about our book back to. We used to have a book that was very heavy previously going back several years, and we've taken a lot of lessons from that to ensure that we understand what reporting on our books that they need to feel comfortable both for the stressed situation as well as the normal situation. But we have been very deliberate about that we are putting on the books. We have not had very much growth came off a very low base in terms of growing that book and again, very deliberate on the types of credits that we're willing to underwrite. So again, from my credit perspective, I feel very comfortable.

componenttext: Chris, we certainly are very analytical and disciplined about how we focus on acquisitions. Quite frankly, our primary focus has been on the bolt-on acquisitions in the nonbank space. componenttext: We look at a lot of different scenarios, Peter, in terms of committing to the 2% to 4%. Our lease at least indicating we can get to 2% to 4% operating leverage are a lot of different scenarios. We believe through our expectations of revenue growth and our expectations of expense management that we'll get there. headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we did say we were looking at 100 to 150 branches. We said we would probably be towards the upper end of that through our strategic planning period. We announced 29 we continue to look each and every day at how to best optimize our branch footprint, wh
componenttext: So we did say we were looking at 100 to 150 branches. We said we would probably be towards the upper end of that through our strategic planning period. We announced 29 we continue to look each and every day at how to best optimize our branch footprint, which has included even growing some of our -- opening some new ones at times, but it's hard to get the cadence down to give you that commitment upfront because it's all facts- and circumstances-based we have to look at our footprint what's going on in the footprint to have a lot of coordination that has to happen. What I can tell you is so we had a $6 million charge on the 29 branches that we closed or made a decision on consolidating this quarter. There'll be another roughly $6 million associated with those branches, so it's [indiscernible] $12 million, and we expect to a payback on that of about 2 years, which is what we've had historically. So not all branches are created equal. We are all little different but if you go back and look at all of our branch consolidation will give you a feel for what that charge might be over time, but it's hard for me to give you a precise timing.

componenttext: No, at this juncture, we just have not seen deposit pressures given the such a fairly modest increase in rates the pressure from any part of our deposit base has been very muted. We continue to watch very closely what our competitors are and to watch very closely what our customers are saying to us. But quite to the contrary, we continue to solve this corner to grow deposit and, in fact, grow low-cost deposits at a pretty healthy base, and so we're just not seeing -- we're not seeing that particular issue arrives at this juncture.

componenttext: Sure. This is David. As Grayson mentioned, we really -- one of our strategic initiatives is to diversify our revenue. And in this context, diversification is away from NII and into NIR. As we think about the desire to diversify and we think about how we can have a more fulsome offering to our customers, things in capital markets have come to mind. So you saw our acquisition of Black Arts Partners, our M&A advisory firm. We looked at the insurance entities, and we'll continue to do that agencies, continue to expand there. We would like to have more solid offering in fixed income sales and trading, so we're looking there. And I think that these acquisitions have a tendency to be smaller acquisitions, but they fit into our need and our desire to continue to diversify and we think it fits very well with our strategy.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And really serve the customer need try and identify the needs of our customers have and how we can serve those better but at the same time, to David's point, diversify our revenue, but we make sure that these are incremental in nature, bolt-on acquisition
componenttext: And really serve the customer need try and identify the needs of our customers have and how we can serve those better but at the same time, to David's point, diversify our revenue, but we make sure that these are incremental in nature, bolt-on acquisitions that have our risk profile that we feel like is prudent. And so I think you can see you should expect the student you to look at those opportunities over 2016, but our primary focus, as you've seen us on organic growth in the markets we're in today with the services we have today, but this is in addition to that, but primary focus is organic growth.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And apologies if somebody mentioned this earlier but in regards to your CCAR 2016, you had a pretty big impact from the stress test last year. Given the decline in oil prices where you are now, do you anticipate a similar decline at this time around
componenttext: Okay. And apologies if somebody mentioned this earlier but in regards to your CCAR 2016, you had a pretty big impact from the stress test last year. Given the decline in oil prices where you are now, do you anticipate a similar decline at this time around and how are you preparing for CCAR into 2016?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so we got a lot of work going on with CCAR to be prepared for our submission in April. We look at a lot of different portfolios. I think from a credit standpoint, we mentioned earlier that X Energy, our credit portfolios are actually improving. And
componenttext: Well, so we got a lot of work going on with CCAR to be prepared for our submission in April. We look at a lot of different portfolios. I think from a credit standpoint, we mentioned earlier that X Energy, our credit portfolios are actually improving. And so that works one way in terms of the CCAR submission. Energy needs to be taken into account. I think, Barb laid out some of the stresses that we're seeing and how we look on from those. So from our standpoint, we have one of the strongest levels of common equity Tier 1 of our peer group. We did return 93% of our earnings to our shareholders, which we think was appropriate and as a result, we didn't want to continue to accrete capital because we felt like we had enough capital to run our business in the prudent manner. So we look at our stresses all the time not just from a CCAR standpoint, we do that for ourselves to make sure we were managing and optimizing our capital in our company, so that we have enough in time to stress and -- but not too much in terms of ensuring we can have an appropriate return to our shareholders. So exactly how all this will manage itself in CCAR, we'll have to see and let it run a lot of programs. We just need to see where the results are. We don't see anything drastically different than what we have submitted before X Energy.

Good morning, and welcome to the Regions Financial Corporation's Quarterly Earnings Call. My name is Paula, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Mr. List Underwood to begin.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. We appreciate your participation in our call today. Our presenters are Grayson Hall, our Chief Executive Officer; and David Turner, our Chief Financial Officer. Other members of management are present as we
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. We appreciate your participation in our call today. Our presenters are Grayson Hall, our Chief Executive Officer; and David Turner, our Chief Financial Officer. Other members of management are present as well and available to answer questions as appropriate. Also, as part of our earnings call, we will be referencing a slide presentation that is available under the Investor Relations section of regions.com.
Also, let me remind you that in the call and potentially in the Q&A that follows, we may make forward-looking statements, which reflect our current views with respect to future events and financial performance. For further details, please reference our forward-looking disclaimer that is located in the Appendix section of the presentation.
With that said, I'll turn it over now to Grayson.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you, List. I want to say just a few words about List Underwood before we get started with our financial results. As we announced earlier this week, List will be retiring at the end of the month. He's been with Regions for 23 years
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you, List. I want to say just a few words about List Underwood before we get started with our financial results. As we announced earlier this week, List will be retiring at the end of the month. He's been with Regions for 23 years and has been a trusted adviser and valued member of our management team. His impressive career spans 43 years and today marks his 90th earnings call with our company.
List, congratulations. We'll certainly miss you as you start your new phase in life and wish you the very best in retirement.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Grayson.
componenttext: Thank you, Grayson.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on to results. Overall, we're pleased and encouraged by our achievements and results in 2015. During the year, we focused on the fundamentals: growing and deepening our customer relationships while also strengthening our financial performance by in
componenttext:
Moving on to results. Overall, we're pleased and encouraged by our achievements and results in 2015. During the year, we focused on the fundamentals: growing and deepening our customer relationships while also strengthening our financial performance by investing in initiatives that will drive revenue growth and create a more efficient and effective organization in the future. As a result, we're a much stronger organization today and are committed to continuing to build sustainable franchise value. 
For the fourth quarter, we reported earnings from continuing operations of $272 million, bringing our full year 2015 total to $1 billion. Earnings per share for the quarter totaled $0.21 per diluted share and $0.76 per diluted share for the full year. These results reflect growth in total adjusted revenue despite a challenging operating environment. 
Importantly, we continue to deliver results in categories that we believe are fundamental to future income growth, including checking accounts, households, Regions360 relationships and credit card accounts. For example, checking accounts grew by more than 2% during the year, and active credit cards increased 11%. We remained focused on expanding and deepening relationships through our need-based approach to relationship banking, and our 2015 results demonstrate that this approach is working.
During the year, we delivered strong average deposit growth of $3 billion or 4%. The mix of our deposits continues to strengthen as 92% are now low-cost deposits. As we have noted before, our markets provide us with the unique and competitive advantages from a deposit composition perspective.
In 2015, we achieved solid adjusted loan growth of $5 billion or 6% from the prior year. Adjusted loans and leases include a lease reclassification adjustment, which David will speak to you shortly. Both business and consumer grew loans with total production for the year of $66 billion or an increase of 12% from 2014. Business lending had an excellent year growing adjusted loans to 7%. Commercial banking, corporate banking and real estate banking all grew loans. And 95% of our markets achieved loan growth, reflecting strength of our business model as local bankers collaborate with industry and product specialists to grow loans. In particular, within Corporate Banking, our specialized industries grew to experience solid growth led by technology and defense as well as franchise restaurant. And the real estate investment trust lending business was strong throughout the year. Consumer lending was also strong in 2015. Total loans exceeded $30 billion at year-end, an increase of 5% over 2014. Mortgage led this growth with loans increasing $496 million or 4%. Additionally, our new point-of-sale initiative bolstered growth in indirect lending with increased loans of $339 million. Additionally, credit card balances increased 7% from the previous year, which drove growth in card and ATM income of $30 million or 9%. 
Total adjusted revenue for the year increased 2% over 2014, reflecting growth in the balance sheet and investments we've made to grow and diversify our revenue. Capital markets income was exceptionally strong, increasing $31 million. Our recent acquisition of BlackArch Partners as well as our planned initiatives are expected to further augment capital markets income in the future. 
Wealth Management had a strong year with income increasing 10% over the prior year. Our focus to grow Wealth Management by continuing to retain, recruit and develop talent was evident in the success of our financial consultants and insurance initiatives. 
During 2015, we executed on our capital plan, returning 93% of earnings to shareholders, which is expected to be one of the highest percentages among our peers. We also made several small yet important investments and acquisitions in 2015 that will help drive future income. These transactions were a prudent and optimal use for our capital, enabling us to expand our capabilities and product offerings to supplement future revenue growth.
With respect to the economic environment, while the U.S. economy is still slow and steadily improving, there is a clear significant pressure from the global economy. Low oil prices continue to create challenges for certain industries while benefiting others. Consequently, we continue to closely monitor our energy portfolio. As expected, there continues to be downward migration in risk ratings in this portfolio. These shifts will continue if oil prices remain at current levels. However, we've remained in close contact with our energy customers. And believe it, we are taking appropriate actions to mitigate vulnerabilities. We continue to prudently build reserves, which now stand at 6% of our direct energy exposure.  As a result, we are cautious, but we expect the future losses related to this portfolio to be managed. 
As we began 2016, we remain committed to our 3 primary strategic initiatives: first, grow and diversify our revenue streams; secondarily, to practice disciplined expense management; and lastly, to effectively deploy our capital. These are all integral to the successful execution of our strategic plan. We continue to operate in a challenging environment that requires us to focus on what we can control. 
To that end, as we discussed in our Investor Day in November of last year, it's essential that we take more aggressive steps as it relates to expense management. Our goal is to eliminate $300 million of core expenses over the next 3 years, approximately 9% of the 2015 adjusted expense base. This plan, which is underway, will help us fund our growth initiatives and build sustainable franchise value. 
In summary, 2015 was a solid year for Regions. We accomplished a great deal while laying the foundation for future earnings growth.
With that, I'll now turn it over to David, who will cover the details for the fourth quarter. David?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. I'll take you through the fourth quarter details and then provide our expectations for 2016. As Grayson noted, 2015 was a solid year for Regions, and the year ended particularly strong, which sets up well -- sets us
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone. I'll take you through the fourth quarter details and then provide our expectations for 2016. As Grayson noted, 2015 was a solid year for Regions, and the year ended particularly strong, which sets up well -- sets us up well for 2016. 
Before I get started, during the fourth quarter Regions corrected the accounting for certain leases, which had previously been included in loans. These leases had been classified as capital leases but were subsequently determined to be operating leases. The cumulative effect on pretax income, lower net interest income and other financing income, $15 million, and reduced the net interest margin by 5 basis points in the quarter. The adjustment resulted in a reclassification of these leases out of loans into other earning assets totaling approximately $834 million at the end of the quarter. The company does not expect this adjustment to have a material impact to net interest income or other financing income or net interest margin in any future reporting period.
With respect to the balance sheet, adjusted loan and lease balances totaled $82 billion at the end of the fourth quarter and were up $1 billion or 1% from the previous quarter. Business lending achieved solid growth with adjusted balances totaling $52 billion at quarter end, an increase of 1%. Adjusted commercial loans grew $563 million or 1%. Commitments increased 2%, and line utilization increased 30 basis points to 46.3%.
Consumer lending had another strong quarter with every loan category increasing. Loans in this portfolio totaled $30 billion, an increase of 1% over the prior quarter. Indirect auto lending increased 2%; and other indirect lending, which includes point-of-sale initiatives, increased $55 million linked quarter or 11%. We are pleased with the results of this new initiative. Year-to-date, loans in this portfolio have increased $339 million, and we expect continued growth in 2016.
Looking at the credit card portfolio, balances increased 6% from the previous quarter, and our penetration rate into our deposit base now stands at 17.3%, up 160 basis points from the fourth quarter of last year.
Mortgage loan balances increased $81 million, and total home equity balances increased $31 million from the previous quarter as new production continue to outpace portfolio runoff.
Let's take a look at deposits. Average deposit balances increased $322 million, and ending balances increased over $1.2 billion during this quarter. Deposit costs remained at historically low levels at 11 basis points, and total funding costs remained low at 26 basis points. With the respect to deposits, we are primarily core deposit-funded with 74% of our deposits coming from consumer and wealth deposits. Low-cost deposits were 92% of total deposits. Approximately half of our deposits come from cities with less than 1 million people, and 50% of our deposits are from customers with $250,000 or less in their account. This is why we believe our deposit bases will be a competitive advantage for us as rates rise.
Let's look at how this impacted our results. Net interest income and other financing income on a fully taxable basis was $856 million, essentially flat with last quarter. However, excluding the impact of the lease adjustment, net interest income and other financing income increased $15 million or 2%. Higher loan balances and balance sheet hedging and optimization strategies were the primary drivers behind the linked-quarter increase along with interest recoveries. The benefit from interest recoveries is not expected to be at this level in the first quarter, approximately $4 million less going forward. The overall increase in net interest income and other financing income was partially offset by fixed asset repricing. The net interest margin was 3.08%. However, excluding the lease adjustment, net interest margin was 3.13% or flat with the previous quarter.
Total noninterest income increased 4% on an adjusted basis from the third quarter, driven primarily by gains on sale of affordable housing investments and by higher card and ATM income. Card and ATM fees increased 3%, primarily related to an increase in commercial bank card usage and increase in the number of active cards of 3.7% and an increase in seasonal consumer spending. Service charges were impacted by posting order changes that went into effect in early November and reduced noninterest income by approximately $7 million. We expect the ongoing impact of this change to be at the lower end of our previously stated $10 million to $15 million quarterly range. 
Wealth Management income was down slightly quarter-over-quarter due to lower insurance income, partially offset by higher investment management and trust fee income.
Capital markets income was relatively flat linked quarter as revenue from new product and service offerings was offset primarily by lower loan syndication fees. 
Let's move on to expenses. Total reported expenses in the fourth quarter were $873 million. On an adjusted basis, expenses totaled $861 million, representing a decline of $33 million or 4% from the prior quarter. This included a decrease of $24 million in FDIC fees, primarily due to additional expenses of $23 million in the third quarter related to prior assessments. The expected quarterly run rate for this expense is in the $22 million to $24 million range, excluding the impact of the proposed FDIC surcharge. Additionally, the fourth quarter benefited from lower expenses related to unfunded commitment cost of $12 million. Salaries and benefits increased $8 million or 2% linked quarter, primarily attributable to $6 million in severance-related expenses. We also incurred $6 million of expenses related to 29 branch consolidations. Our adjusted efficiency ratio was 63.4% in the fourth quarter. But excluding the $15 million lease adjustment, the adjusted efficiency ratio was 62.7%.
As discussed at Investor Day, we will continue to make investments to grow our business. However, we must be more efficient in everything we do. As Grayson noted, our plan to become a more efficient organization, including the elimination of $300 million in core expenses, is underway.
Let's move on to asset quality. Total net charge-offs increased $18 million to $78 million and represented 38 basis points of average loans. This increase was primarily related to one large charge-off in the energy loan portfolio. Total business services criticized and classified loans increased to $117 million, driven by some weakening in a small number of larger loans, primarily within the energy portfolio. However, total nonaccrual loans, excluding loans held for sale, declined from the third quarter. Troubled debt restructured loans, or TDRs, also declined, down 1% from the prior quarter. The provision for loan losses was $69 million, and our allowance for loan losses was down 2 basis points to 1.36% at the end of the fourth quarter. And at quarter end, our loan loss allowance to nonaccrual loans or coverage ratio was 141%. 
Now regarding our energy portfolio, while oil prices have declined, exposure remains manageable. Should oil prices remain at current levels, charge-offs will be in the $50 million to $75 million range in 2016. The energy charge-off taken this quarter reduces the previous range of $50 million to $100 million. Additionally, we have currently have just over $150 million reserved or 6% of our direct energy exposure. And given where we are in the credit cycle, the volatility in certain credit metrics can be expected, especially related to larger dollar commercial credits in our portfolio and fluctuating commodity prices.
Let's move on to capital and liquidity. During 2015, we returned $925 million to shareholders, which included the repurchase of $621 million of common stock and $304 million in dividends. Under Basel III, the Tier 1 ratio was estimated at 11.7%, and the common equity Tier 1 ratio was estimated at 10.9%. On a fully phased-in basis, common equity Tier 1 was estimated at 10.7%, well above current regulatory minimums. Our loan-to-deposit ratio at the end of the quarter was 83%. And at the end of the quarter, we were fully compliant as it relates to the liquidity coverage ratio.
Now let me give you an overview of our current expectations for 2016. We expect total loan growth to be in the 3% to 5% range on an average basis, excluding the impact of the operating lease reclassification. And regarding deposits, we expect full year average deposit growth in the 2% to 4% range. And commensurate with our loan growth projections, we expect net interest income and other financing income to increase in the 2% to 4% range. Now should we experience no additional rate increases, we expect to be at the lower end of that range. As a result of our investments, we expect to grow adjusted noninterest income somewhere in the 4% to 6% range. And we will continue to make investments in 2016, however, we have also begun to execute our plan to eliminate $300 million of core expenses, of which 35% to 45% will occur in 2016. Therefore, we expect total adjusted noninterest expenses in 2016 to be flat to up modestly from 2015.
We expect to achieve an efficiency ratio of less than 63% in 2016 and positive operating leverage somewhere in the 2% to 4% range. Now we still expect our net charge-offs to be in the 25 to 35 basis point range. However, given the current price of oil, we would expect to be at the top end of that range. 
In closing, the fourth quarter was a strong finish to a solid year. The investments we've made in 2015 positions us well for 2016 and beyond, and we look forward to updating you on the progress throughout the year as we continue to build sustainable franchise value.
With that, we thank you for your time and attention this morning.  I will now turn it back over to List for instructions on the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ryan Nash of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ryan Nash of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe we'll just start off on credit. On -- first, can you give -- maybe give us a little bit more color on the loss you took, what type of loan was it? Is there any credit left? And then I guess when you think about the reserve that you've taken, the rou
componenttext: Maybe we'll just start off on credit. On -- first, can you give -- maybe give us a little bit more color on the loss you took, what type of loan was it? Is there any credit left? And then I guess when you think about the reserve that you've taken, the roughly 6%, what is your reserve contemplate for oil prices? And we've heard others say that if oil prices stayed at this level, you could see another incremental amount of provision. Just wondering what that number would be for you.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Barb Godin, Ryan. Let me go ahead and answer that first part of the question, and I'll address the second part. The first part was an energy credit that sit around for a few years with M&A activity, which originally led to the credit. It is the Share
componenttext: It's Barb Godin, Ryan. Let me go ahead and answer that first part of the question, and I'll address the second part. The first part was an energy credit that sit around for a few years with M&A activity, which originally led to the credit. It is the Shared National Credit. There are 5 banks involved. And we saw some distress in this credit in the early part of the year, so we have been working this credit really hard during the course of the year. And it simply came to conclusion near the end of the year. And what we've done is we have appropriately marked that credit. We've taken the loss on that credit, as you've heard, and we've moved the residual balance into our held for sale, and we anticipate that we will have that out of our held-for-sale numbers by the end of -- we're hoping January but, certainly this quarter, it will be out of our numbers. And back to individual credit, the charge-off on that was approximately $25 million, just for rounding. In terms of how we think about our reserve and look at prices as we work our way through our process, in the backs of our minds, if we look at our price deck, our price deck is roughly $36 right now; sensitivity, $28.90. So we're looking in that range as we determine and establish what those numbers should be, but we're also looking very heavily at each and every individual customer, what their cash flow looks like, what our collateral looks like, what our asset coverage is. We currently have asset coverage of 1.71x and the E&P book as an example. So again, in conversations, and we have them ongoing, conversations with our customers because we really do have a small number of customers, we still believe that repayment ability is adequate with them and again establish our reserves accordingly.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then David had commented in his prepared remarks that you're expecting charge-offs to be towards the high end of the 25 to 35. I guess from both a portfolio, whether it's metals and minings or some other related areas, or even if it's across d
componenttext: Got it. And then David had commented in his prepared remarks that you're expecting charge-offs to be towards the high end of the 25 to 35. I guess from both a portfolio, whether it's metals and minings or some other related areas, or even if it's across different geographies, whether it's Texas or Louisiana or anywhere else that's exposed to oil and gas, are you seeing any other sort of changing in credit patterns where there's fix up in delinquencies or anything that's having impact on either growth or the overall credit performance?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We're keeping a really close eye on all of that. There is some pressure certainly on commodities in general across the industry, as you know, and that's just given the strong U.S. dollar, what's going on in Europe and in China in terms of the dislocat
componenttext: No. We're keeping a really close eye on all of that. There is some pressure certainly on commodities in general across the industry, as you know, and that's just given the strong U.S. dollar, what's going on in Europe and in China in terms of the dislocation of the markets. So there is some pressure there, but we've seen nothing yet that is significantly concerning.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Maybe one -- just one last quick one. David, just -- can you help us understand the trajectory of the net interest margin, I guess -- and maybe both based on the forward curve? And if we don't get any additional rate hike in '16,  where do you
componenttext: All right. Maybe one -- just one last quick one. David, just -- can you help us understand the trajectory of the net interest margin, I guess -- and maybe both based on the forward curve? And if we don't get any additional rate hike in '16,  where do you think the NIM would trend over the course of the year?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ryan, I gave a little bit of guidance in terms of if we don't get another change, we'll be at the lower end of our 2% to 4% guidance that we've given you. I also gave you a little bit of guidance in my prepared comments in terms of margin. We did hav
componenttext: Yes. Ryan, I gave a little bit of guidance in terms of if we don't get another change, we'll be at the lower end of our 2% to 4% guidance that we've given you. I also gave you a little bit of guidance in my prepared comments in terms of margin. We did have unusual recovery, interest recoveries. We think about $4 million that won't repeat going forward, but we're looking for a relatively stable NIM, and this is adjusting, by the way, for lease accounting. So we were at 3.08% on net interest margin, 5 points related to lease adjustments. So 3.13% would have made us flat, and we're looking for a relatively stable -- and just to remind everybody, that's been 1 or 2 points either side of where we are for 2016. And so we're looking for that guidance in terms of growth in NII that we've really been focusing on to be that 2% to 4% through the year. So you may see some unusual changes in a given quarter, but you got to keep the year in mind when thinking about NIIs or trajectory.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Eads of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Eads of UBS.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe following up on energy, when I look at the -- you guys added some disclosure on the criticized loans, which I think was pretty interesting. And when you look at it, the criticized loans are actually higher as a percentage basis in the E&P portfolio
componenttext: Maybe following up on energy, when I look at the -- you guys added some disclosure on the criticized loans, which I think was pretty interesting. And when you look at it, the criticized loans are actually higher as a percentage basis in the E&P portfolio compared to oilfield services. So I was wondering if you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing that -- it seems -- have you more comfortable with the exposures on the E&P side and I guess maybe a little bit less though on the oilfield services.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, it's Barb Godin. I'll be happy to answer that. As we do our redeterminations, and we just finished up our fall redeterminations just about then, what happens is as you readjust the borrowing base, and again, for fall redeterminations this year, bor
componenttext: Again, it's Barb Godin. I'll be happy to answer that. As we do our redeterminations, and we just finished up our fall redeterminations just about then, what happens is as you readjust the borrowing base, and again, for fall redeterminations this year, borrowing base adjustments downwards were a little under 8%, notwithstanding if that costs us an overadvance. So what we will immediately do is call that loan a criticized loan and move it into a nonpast category. So again, that would account for the reason that we have roughly 48% of our E&P book that is showing right now as criticized. Having said that, we have a rigorous process as well around our oilfield services portfolio. As you can see on the chart that we did provide, 32 customers make up 75% of that portfolio. So we're able to stay in constant and close contact with them. Again, as we see any weakness in there, again, we are very quick to move it into a criticized category.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe to follow up on that, on -- so E&P portfolio, if you have -- if close to half of the loans were in -- a lot of those were in a overadvanced position, I would think that they'd only be in a further overadvanced position now that where oil prices
componenttext: Just maybe to follow up on that, on -- so E&P portfolio, if you have -- if close to half of the loans were in -- a lot of those were in a overadvanced position, I would think that they'd only be in a further overadvanced position now that where oil prices have gone since the redetermination was fleet. So would that suggest that criticized loans -- that real criticized exposure might even be higher than that?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The spring redetermination that we did, that was somewhere between, I'll let you choose, roughly 15% reduction in borrowing bases. And now we're seeing that there's an incremental 8%, I'll round it up, on top of that. So roughly 23% reduction in borro
componenttext: No. The spring redetermination that we did, that was somewhere between, I'll let you choose, roughly 15% reduction in borrowing bases. And now we're seeing that there's an incremental 8%, I'll round it up, on top of that. So roughly 23% reduction in borrowing base. Remember as well in the industry, customers get a 6-month cure period in which they're able to cure, and we have seen the number of customers -- again, those earlier in the year that had access to the capital markets. And even now, those that are still very strong still don't have access to capital markets, and they're able to take themselves out of an overadvanced position.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just as we think about the dislocations we're seeing in the markets right now, I know it's fairly early. But do you guys have any sense of how that -- if this continues, how that would impact the strategy you guys have for growing the
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just as we think about the dislocations we're seeing in the markets right now, I know it's fairly early. But do you guys have any sense of how that -- if this continues, how that would impact the strategy you guys have for growing the capital market, the Wealth Management business? Is there anything that's pretty sensitive to market activity levels? And will you be more concerned about the growth trajectory?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll tell you that we are creating these new products and services. The driver of that is because our customers need that, and we're looking to have a more fulsome offering to our customers. And we're out there talking to them and feel very
componenttext: This is David. I'll tell you that we are creating these new products and services. The driver of that is because our customers need that, and we're looking to have a more fulsome offering to our customers. And we're out there talking to them and feel very good about where they stand right now, which is why I reiterated our guidance for 2016 on things like loan growth being in the 3% to 5%. We're seeing in our discussions with our customers, we still see the domestic economy being okay. We're looking at 2%, 2.5% GDP. And so there is that dislocation that's happening here of late, but as we see our customers, we believe they need the products and services. The capital markets investments we're making we think are going to be very strong and looking for that to continue and help us get to that 4% to 6% growth rate that we're expecting in noninterest revenue.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And wanted to ask about energy again. Just wondering here with regard to oil, if declines further to $20, $25, let's say, what are your potential losses there?
componenttext: And wanted to ask about energy again. Just wondering here with regard to oil, if declines further to $20, $25, let's say, what are your potential losses there?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we look at -- and I'll ask Barb to reiterate and complete the statement. But we look at our energy portfolio, we have got a very disciplined process of calculating probability defaults and loss given defaults. We've got the redeterminations that
componenttext: Well, as we look at -- and I'll ask Barb to reiterate and complete the statement. But we look at our energy portfolio, we have got a very disciplined process of calculating probability defaults and loss given defaults. We've got the redeterminations that we're doing on the E&P portfolio twice a year. And so we feel good about the level of rigor and discipline around our process that drives that evaluation of how much we reserve based on what we think the incurred losses may be. And so I think our confidence in that process is very solid. We're staying disciplined around that process. And if oil prices continue to decline, that process is going to drive risk ratings down on some of our credits and will drive a higher level of criticized classified loans and think will drive how we reserve against those loans. But it will be on incurred-loss basis. And until that incurred loss occurs from an accounting perspective, our process is going to determine it. So Barb, do you want to add, too?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what I would add to that is the operative word here being how long will oil prices stay depressed, and you mentioned somewhere in the $20 a barrel range. And again, if it's in the $20 a barrel range and it stays there for an entire year, it could
componenttext: I think what I would add to that is the operative word here being how long will oil prices stay depressed, and you mentioned somewhere in the $20 a barrel range. And again, if it's in the $20 a barrel range and it stays there for an entire year, it could be in terms of charge-offs. This is not provision. It could be up to an incremental $50 million. And that is based on some back of the envelope versus anything precise, I would have to tell you. But again, that's not our view, and I don't think it's the view of the industry at this point that oil is going to stay sub-$30 for any length of time.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I tried to give you a little bit more global view of where we thought NII and margin was going. So we start breaking it down. We get pretty granular. There's puts and takes either way. If you just want to focus on that component of the December in
componenttext: Yes, so I tried to give you a little bit more global view of where we thought NII and margin was going. So we start breaking it down. We get pretty granular. There's puts and takes either way. If you just want to focus on that component of the December increase, we're probably benefiting in the $5 million to $10 million range in the first quarter. But remember, there are some other things going the other way. You got day counts, about $5 million working against you. You got the interest reversal of $4 million that I talked about in my prepared comments. So I think it's better to kind of look overall at the guidance in terms of relatively stable margin and growth in NII in that 2% to 4% range, commensurate with the loan growth that we talked about, the 3% to 5%.
