componenttext: Right. So if you're talking about a 2- or 3-ish percent normalized increase from just salaries and expense inflation, then we're looking at over a 3-year period, an outlook where you should be able to bring your expense dollars down over a 3-year period. Is that fair?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the things that's important to us strategically as we laid out in Investor Day is to grow and diversify our revenue and to continue to make investments. In order to make those investments, we have to -- and control expenses at the same time,
componenttext: Well, one of the things that's important to us strategically as we laid out in Investor Day is to grow and diversify our revenue and to continue to make investments. In order to make those investments, we have to -- and control expenses at the same time, we have to have savings from our kind of our core operations. And that's really what the $300 million, now $400 million is all about. And so we have to continue to find other ways to become more efficient because it is critically important for us to continue to grow our company and to grow noninterest revenue, in particular. And so having a reduction in expense versus having a flat to up modestly, which is what we have today, and again, we'll give you 2017 and beyond, but it will be somewhere in that range as well.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So yes, I'm -- what I'm missing in my little calculation is the investment spending you're making. Okay. Okay. And then just separately, you no longer have to deal with the qualitative part of the CCAR test. I know the regulators say that they're go
componenttext: Okay. So yes, I'm -- what I'm missing in my little calculation is the investment spending you're making. Okay. Okay. And then just separately, you no longer have to deal with the qualitative part of the CCAR test. I know the regulators say that they're going to be assessing your process in the normal course regulation. But maybe you could give us a sense as to how much that helps you in terms of dealing, not only with the CCAR itself at that point in time in the year, but also how you think about the capital return that might open up for you without the qualitative test issue that you have had to deal with over the past years.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would start with, obviously, the -- it's still just the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. So we still need finalization there. But based on what is out there, I think it's constructive for the industry, for the regional bank space. That being said, we m
componenttext: So I would start with, obviously, the -- it's still just the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. So we still need finalization there. But based on what is out there, I think it's constructive for the industry, for the regional bank space. That being said, we manage our capital in the manner that we've laid out at capital planning process and all the governance, and none of that is going to change. We're going to continue to have robust capital planning and loss forecasting. What this does is that plus learnings that we get from each CCAR filing help us frame up what we can do with our capital. First and foremost, we want to leverage our capital to grow organically. And that's the first order of business. We want to make investments to -- for bolt-on acquisitions that we've done. You saw the one that we released yesterday. Those are important. Having a fair dividend to our shareholders is important. And then when we have excess capital that we're generating, having an appropriate return in the form of a share buyback is in order. So I think given all of that, it gives us an ability to think about capital targets relative to the risk that we have in our balance sheet. We've leverage -- we've mentioned that based on today's risk that we have that, that Common Equity Tier 1 ratio in the 9.5% is where we would target over time, and we're at approximately 11%. So we have capital to be put to work or to be given back to shareholders over time. And so I think all the body of evidence that we have will help us manage that in a prudent manner over perhaps a shorter period of time. We have to think through that, though, Betsy. It's a little early to tell what that exactly means for our CCAR submission in 2017.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Betsy. It's Barb again. What we have is effectively multifamily 3 credits, 2 of them are in the Houston area, 1 within Oklahoma. The one in the Houston area, I'll give you a little more color on. Higher concessions than originally expected, bu
componenttext: Absolutely, Betsy. It's Barb again. What we have is effectively multifamily 3 credits, 2 of them are in the Houston area, 1 within Oklahoma. The one in the Houston area, I'll give you a little more color on. Higher concessions than originally expected, but we moved that to a special mention loan. Another that was also in the Houston area. Construction delays due to rainfall. So we moved that one over. And the last one is in Oklahoma, 93% complete on that building, marginally behind schedule in terms of the leasing, but we still expect completion of the building by the end of December. So again, we look at everything relative to how you were supposed to be performing in any of these credits. And if you're not performing as per what we originally laid out, we will move you to a special mention. The transportation credits are energy-related. One large transportation credit, energy-related. What I would say, though, about our overall criticized book is that 93% of our criticized book in the business services area is paying as agreed. So I don't expect at the end of the day that there'll be a significant number of losses at all coming from any of those loans that we moved over.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Separate question on your branch sales incentives. Grayson, do you expect any meaningful change to your branch sales incentives given the backdrop of what's happened with Wells?
componenttext: Okay. Separate question on your branch sales incentives. Grayson, do you expect any meaningful change to your branch sales incentives given the backdrop of what's happened with Wells?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think given the backdrop that the industry is facing right now, I think that the prudent thing to do, and I assume all of our competitors are doing that, is taking a very deep dive on all of our sales practices using both our internal leadership, i
componenttext: Yes, I think given the backdrop that the industry is facing right now, I think that the prudent thing to do, and I assume all of our competitors are doing that, is taking a very deep dive on all of our sales practices using both our internal leadership, internal experts as well as external advisers to rechallenge ourselves on all of our sales practices. We're quite proud of the culture we've built at Regions. We've had a sales culture that is really based on shared values, making sure that it's customer-focused and that we're doing the right thing for customers in the right way. And our messaging is quite strong, and the feedback we get from surveys and external sources is very encouraging. But all that being said, we believe in the backdrop of all that's going on, that we're all rechallenging ourselves to make sure that everything is done correctly and appropriately. And that activity is going on here, as I'm sure as it's going on everywhere. But as I've said, we've got a lot of confidence in the processes we've built. We think we're doing the right things, but more importantly, we think we're doing them the right way. But we got to make sure that, that's occurring in all aspects. And so given the backdrop, we're reviewing everything we're doing.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Steve Moss of FBR.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Steve Moss of FBR.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: I just want to circle back on expenses a little bit. I know in the past you've talked about pulling forward expenses. And I was wondering, you know what's the possibility that the $300 million you could complete it in 2017?

componenttext: Yes. So we are continuing to challenge ourselves on the $300 million plus, additional $100 million, in terms of timing and are looking to pull forward as much as prudent without harming the long-term franchise. So I can't give you a probability of being able to complete that in 2017. I think getting all of that in 2017 will be very difficult. But could we move some of it? That is currently in 2018 and '17, I think that's an appropriate challenge to our team. And we'll be coming back again after this challenge. And in December, at our next conference, we'll lay out what that 3-year plan looks like, including metrics like operating leverage and efficiency and just total expense bogey as well.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just another follow-up on expenses. The additional $100 million that you identified, is there -- and I'm sorry if I missed this, is there any change in kind of the complexion of what that $100 million comprises relative to the $300 million that you laid o
componenttext: Just another follow-up on expenses. The additional $100 million that you identified, is there -- and I'm sorry if I missed this, is there any change in kind of the complexion of what that $100 million comprises relative to the $300 million that you laid out the Investor Day?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Michael those are -- if you go back to Investor Day, you'll see roughly 4 broad categories of expense. I suspect they'll fall into those categories. I think you should expect us to leverage -- see us leveraging technology a bit more, which gives us ti
componenttext: No. Michael those are -- if you go back to Investor Day, you'll see roughly 4 broad categories of expense. I suspect they'll fall into those categories. I think you should expect us to leverage -- see us leveraging technology a bit more, which gives us time to put things in place to help us from an efficiency standpoint. So that could be one of the changes. As we go through this, we kind of started on the human capital side and then getting into really third-party spend, which we've done some of. There's probably some more room there. We continue to work on occupancy costs and branch consolidations of the office space. As you know, we had 1 million square feet we wanted to take out over the initial 3-year period in time. We're in good shape with that, but we're continuing to challenge ourselves on those kinds of areas. We think there will be more to come there.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say that most of the kind of heavy-lifting from the expenses efforts have been realized at this point? One of your competitors this morning, basically, said that they had anything kind of incremental beyond today's announcement would be much
componenttext: Is it fair to say that most of the kind of heavy-lifting from the expenses efforts have been realized at this point? One of your competitors this morning, basically, said that they had anything kind of incremental beyond today's announcement would be much smaller. Is that a similar view for you guys? Or if you were to take a more critical view of your branch network, could you actually see some more material savings as we move forward?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, Michael, you look at the past few years, we've been very focused on efficiency and trying to find expenses. And obviously, the duration of this operating environment has continued to put substantial pressure on expense management. And a lot of
componenttext: No. I mean, Michael, you look at the past few years, we've been very focused on efficiency and trying to find expenses. And obviously, the duration of this operating environment has continued to put substantial pressure on expense management. And a lot of the easy first steps are all behind us in terms of expense management. And really, what you're doing now is having to sort of transform how you do business. And if you look at the investments we've made in a lot of our digital channels, investments we've made in sort of retooling our branches and how we operate out of our branches, we're really, at this point in time, having to really challenge ourselves on how we go to market in certain parts of the company. And as David said, using technology to make those people more efficient and more effective. So to answer your question, easy expense saves are long behind us, have been for a while. And so the things we're doing now are much more transformative. You know, interesting, take a little more longer to execute. But at this juncture, you really have to look at how you do business rather than just trying to look at normal inefficiencies of process.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And maybe just one more for Barb on energy. I appreciate the guidance around charge-offs for energy reiteration that you provided. What would cause it to be kind of at the lower end of the range? And then what sort of variables would
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And maybe just one more for Barb on energy. I appreciate the guidance around charge-offs for energy reiteration that you provided. What would cause it to be kind of at the lower end of the range? And then what sort of variables would cause you to be at the upper end -- or that $75 million?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. It's clearly oil prices, where they sit right now, generally around that $50 area that provides some stabilization. But we honestly don't believe that things will really move in the right direction until we get somewhere in that $60 a barrel
componenttext: Yes, Michael. It's clearly oil prices, where they sit right now, generally around that $50 area that provides some stabilization. But we honestly don't believe that things will really move in the right direction until we get somewhere in that $60 a barrel range, give or take. But if they stay at $50, we do see stabilization in our metrics. If they go down into, again, you saw our guidance of sub $30, we would expect significant increases, i.e. being an additional $100 million. But if oil got down into the $30 a barrel range as well, we would also see some upward pressure on our -- all of our credit metrics and then our charge-offs as well. And by the way, just for some more color on the energy charge-offs that we did have this quarter, of the $6 million that we had, roughly $1.5 million was coal. So year-to-date, we've had $23 million in energy charge-offs. And of that, approximately $9.5 million, $10 million is related to the coal portion of our book as well.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Geoffrey Elliott of Autonomous Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Geoffrey Elliott of Autonomous Research.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your prepared remarks, I think you mentioned examining strategic alternatives to increase revenues or reduce expenses. I wonder if you could elaborate on what you were referring to there.
componenttext: In your prepared remarks, I think you mentioned examining strategic alternatives to increase revenues or reduce expenses. I wonder if you could elaborate on what you were referring to there.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we talk about strategy, indeed, the things like we saw yesterday with our announcement of First Sterling, continuing to make any type of investments that are helping us to serve our customers to give us a more full-some offering to our custom
componenttext: Yes. So when we talk about strategy, indeed, the things like we saw yesterday with our announcement of First Sterling, continuing to make any type of investments that are helping us to serve our customers to give us a more full-some offering to our customer base as we seek to meet their needs. There are other investments that we seek to make. We talked a little bit about leveraging technology to help us from our cost standpoint over time. So we're looking at different technologies to help us look at process improvement to help us where we might be able to get a better answer to take labor out and improve our internal control structure for making those type of technology investments. So those were kind of the ideas we had.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we really believe the best strategy for us at this point in time is to really focus on executing our plans. We've got plans that allow us to continue to improve the fundamentals of the company. If you look at the fundamentals, the fundamentals are po
componenttext: Yes, we really believe the best strategy for us at this point in time is to really focus on executing our plans. We've got plans that allow us to continue to improve the fundamentals of the company. If you look at the fundamentals, the fundamentals are posting up some very good numbers, and in particular, on the consumer side of our house, but really across the board. And so that focus on execution is a key point of what we do. And the other side is innovation. I think, in this market, you've got to be able to execute, which is also got to be able to innovate. And so we're spending an awful lot of time trying to figure out how we innovate in a way that better serves our customers and does it in a way that creates greater efficiency in the way we operate. So I think that we got a number of good strategic moves that we're making that will help improve the overall performance of the company.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like the focus is more around bolt-on acquisitions where you think you can do something to improve efficiency rather than selling businesses, which you look at, and you don't think they fit anymore?
componenttext: So it sounds like the focus is more around bolt-on acquisitions where you think you can do something to improve efficiency rather than selling businesses, which you look at, and you don't think they fit anymore?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, actually, what we've done thus far is that you've seen our advancements on things like our Green Sky Initiative, [indiscernible] Closing initiative. We do challenge ourselves on our businesses to ensure that they're seeking appropriate retur
componenttext: Yes. I think, actually, what we've done thus far is that you've seen our advancements on things like our Green Sky Initiative, [indiscernible] Closing initiative. We do challenge ourselves on our businesses to ensure that they're seeking appropriate return -- risk-adjusted return on the business. And when we have a business that can't help us, meet our return hurdles and/or don't serve our customer, then we'll challenge ourselves on that. But right now, it's been investments to really help us grow and diversify revenue, and that diversification is moving a little bit away from NII to NIR. It's moving geographically. It's diversifying in products and services that we offer to give us a little more balance in terms of how we generate revenue and earnings for our shareholders.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jill Shea of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jill Shea of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just on fees. You're on pace to grow fee income by more than 6% this year, and you had some nice growth across capital markets, card and wealth. Can you just speak to some of the momentum that you're seeing in your fee income the remainder of this y
componenttext: Maybe just on fees. You're on pace to grow fee income by more than 6% this year, and you had some nice growth across capital markets, card and wealth. Can you just speak to some of the momentum that you're seeing in your fee income the remainder of this year and into next?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I'll ask John Owen to take the word to sort of talk about some of our fee rates businesses and some of our growth rates you're seeing there, it's a very encouraging story.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I'll ask John Owen to take the word to sort of talk about some of our fee rates businesses and some of our growth rates you're seeing there, it's a very encouraging story.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Grayson. Good morning, everyone. As Grayson said, we're seeing steady improvement in our consumer business. If you look at our account growth standpoint, we're growing checking accounts about 2.5%, debit card growth of about 4% year-over-yea
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Grayson. Good morning, everyone. As Grayson said, we're seeing steady improvement in our consumer business. If you look at our account growth standpoint, we're growing checking accounts about 2.5%, debit card growth of about 4% year-over-year, credit cards growth of about 12% year-over-year. We're now making customer account growth of about 14%. The other point I would make is utilization of debit cards, both total transactions and spend is up as well on cards. So those are driving a lot of our increases.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just maybe any color on capital markets and wealth and maybe some of the momentum you're seeing there?
componenttext: And then just maybe any color on capital markets and wealth and maybe some of the momentum you're seeing there?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is John Turner. We're continuing to build out our debt capital markets platform and doing that across a number of different products and capabilities. So what you've seen is we've grown capital markets revenues significantly over the last 2 yea
componenttext: Sure. This is John Turner. We're continuing to build out our debt capital markets platform and doing that across a number of different products and capabilities. So what you've seen is we've grown capital markets revenues significantly over the last 2 years as the introduction of some of those products and capabilities. We had a very nice third quarter, largely built on the M&A advisory revenue that we generated. We also had a pretty good quarter in real estate permanent placements, particularly through our Fannie DUS license. We expect to continue to see that kind of growth going forward, as we continue to leverage these new capabilities. We're excited about the acquisition of the First Sterling businesses. Community investment capital business is one that's been very important to us. We decided that we wanted to grow that business strategically 2 years ago. We've set out to find a syndication platform that would help us build out some distribution capabilities that we didn't have. So again, that's another product capability that we have that will allow us to meet customer needs, grow revenue in a more diverse and balanced way. And we expect to see, again, nice growth in capital markets and in 2017 as we leverage more of these capabilities.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Matt Burnell of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Matt Burnell of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on margin. I thought I've heard David mention something about some loan repricing efforts that you've been able to pass through. I'm curious if there's more of that to come and what the benefit might be going forward. And I guess in a related quest
componenttext: First, on margin. I thought I've heard David mention something about some loan repricing efforts that you've been able to pass through. I'm curious if there's more of that to come and what the benefit might be going forward. And I guess in a related question to David, how do you think a 25 basis point hike, if we're lucky enough to get it in December, would benefit Q1 margin? Last year, it was about a 5 basis point benefit quarter-over-quarter on an adjusted basis. Should we see something similar in the first quarter, if we were to get the 25 basis points?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll start with your second question first. And I think when you look at 25 basis points and see where we're positioned, you're probably, for the year, in that $15 million to $20 million range. So your number is not too far off for the first quart
componenttext: Yes. So I'll start with your second question first. And I think when you look at 25 basis points and see where we're positioned, you're probably, for the year, in that $15 million to $20 million range. So your number is not too far off for the first quarter. I would tell you, as we think about the returns, improving our returns, that's not just a pricing issue only. It's really the relationship. It's trying to get the relationship return up, which can include credit, whether it's going to include all the other products and services that we offer that customer. And so we certainly are looking at things that have a credit-only relationship that have a suboptimal return for us. And those are the ones we want to try and get the relationship, get our pricing through, get our returns better or recycling and leveraging that capital into another option or another alternative. So I think, over time, what you ought to see is, we should have some positive impacts to margin, the pace of which is really dependent on how we change this whole relationship and whether its credit-related or product and service-driven.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add, as we look at yields, going on spreads over a lot more did improve during the quarter. More importantly, though, as David talked about, I think what you're seeing is growth in fee revenue, a growth in deposits, all because of our focus o
componenttext: I would just add, as we look at yields, going on spreads over a lot more did improve during the quarter. More importantly, though, as David talked about, I think what you're seeing is growth in fee revenue, a growth in deposits, all because of our focus on relationship returns. And just to underscore, the work that's being done, talk about our corporate banking portfolio, particularly Shared National Credit book, and our desire to improve returns in that business, we actually exited almost $2 billion worth of credit in the first 9 months of the year. We reallocated that capital back into new relationships and existing relationships. And in doing that, we increased the revenue per relationship over 50% and the risk-adjusted returns in the business by almost 250 basis points. So we are seeing that activity really begin to have an impact, it will take some time to see it in the P&L. We believe that it is occurring and it's the right approach.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Matt, I'll add. This is David. In terms of kind of margin expectations, I've tried to put in the prepared comments, we had a couple of things that are fairly usual in the fourth quarter that pushed our margin down to the 306 that we think rebounds a b
componenttext: And Matt, I'll add. This is David. In terms of kind of margin expectations, I've tried to put in the prepared comments, we had a couple of things that are fairly usual in the fourth quarter that pushed our margin down to the 306 that we think rebounds a bit in that 309 range, give or take a lot of -- there are a lot of things that can move. But based on best evidence we have today, we'd be in that range. And I gave you about $11 million of NII that was a bit different for the quarter that we think helps give you some stability in terms of NII and resulting margins for the fourth quarter.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Now that makes sense, David. And actually, your comments earlier about the repricing and relationship are a nice segue into my final question. Specific to the capital markets business, how far along are you relative to where you'd ultimately like to
componenttext: Sure. Now that makes sense, David. And actually, your comments earlier about the repricing and relationship are a nice segue into my final question. Specific to the capital markets business, how far along are you relative to where you'd ultimately like to get, in terms of cross-selling those investment banking, capital markets products, into your corporate middle-market customer -- credit customer base?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John Turner. I would say, we're probably 70% along in developing -- 70%, 75% developing the product capabilities that we'd like to have in our debt capital markets business. And maybe 20% to 25% along in terms of really capturing what we think is
componenttext: This is John Turner. I would say, we're probably 70% along in developing -- 70%, 75% developing the product capabilities that we'd like to have in our debt capital markets business. And maybe 20% to 25% along in terms of really capturing what we think is the opportunity within the business. Today, about 24% of our total revenue in the Corporate Banking business is noninterest revenue. And we'd like to see that number improve to 40-plus percent over time, which means we've effectively got to double the business. And we think that there's visibility to get there. It'll take a while, but we see the opportunity clearly.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kenneth Usdin of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kenneth Usdin of Jefferies.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up on credit. You talked about the quality of the book improving over time as you remix. This quarter, we still saw your ability to -- with the energy improvement, to release some reserves, and the overall reserve for loans ratio is
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up on credit. You talked about the quality of the book improving over time as you remix. This quarter, we still saw your ability to -- with the energy improvement, to release some reserves, and the overall reserve for loans ratio is still quite high versus almost all peers at 14. So just can you talk about philosophically, over time, with that change in the mix of the business, do we see that reserve to loans ratio continue to come down? And as credit continues to improve on energy, is there more room to still be releasing as we continue to see the improvements on the resi side as much as the potential improvements in energy?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken. It's Barb. And so as we book loans -- book new loans, we're always going to have a provision associated with those. So we'll put that as a positive to increase the provision. On the other side, as our book continues to get better and our ratings
componenttext: Yes, Ken. It's Barb. And so as we book loans -- book new loans, we're always going to have a provision associated with those. So we'll put that as a positive to increase the provision. On the other side, as our book continues to get better and our ratings improve on all of these credits, we'd also have the opportunity then, again, to reduce our overall provision on these. So net-net, over time, if we're suggesting that we're going to have a book that's stable to some continued improvement, then you should see some stability in the provision too improving. And again, a lot of that still will be driven by energy, you saw that this quarter. So as the number of energy credits got much better, we were able to reduce our overall level of provision, roughly $50 million in that book. And we'll continue to review that book every quarter as we move through the next several quarters and see how that impacts our overall numbers.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is -- first to follow-up. Do you expect that the new stuff that you're adding on the consumer side, is that higher loss rate content? And do you have any change in kind of philosophical -- like what you're through-the-cycle loss rate should be, under
componenttext: That is -- first to follow-up. Do you expect that the new stuff that you're adding on the consumer side, is that higher loss rate content? And do you have any change in kind of philosophical -- like what you're through-the-cycle loss rate should be, understanding there's a lot of current things that are plus and minus underneath?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, our overall, philosophically, we stated 75 basis points of loss through the cycle. We still believe that that's the right number. Consumer book was heavily weighted towards real estate. And again, real estate tracking in those low double-digi
componenttext: Yes. I mean, our overall, philosophically, we stated 75 basis points of loss through the cycle. We still believe that that's the right number. Consumer book was heavily weighted towards real estate. And again, real estate tracking in those low double-digit numbers in terms of losses, but also doesn't give you the returns like some of the other products that we're looking at do give us. So the answer is, yes, we will see some increased product cost on the consumer side, although we think again, they're going to be quite manageable. We do have limits, some concentrations on any of those new initiatives that we do.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Eads of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Eads of UBS.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up for Barb. Your -- on -- can you give us a little bit of color on about what you're seeing in the oilfield services portfolio? Looks like you've had some declines in balances and commitments, but you had a tick-up in credits side? I
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up for Barb. Your -- on -- can you give us a little bit of color on about what you're seeing in the oilfield services portfolio? Looks like you've had some declines in balances and commitments, but you had a tick-up in credits side? I mean, one of the things with that portfolio really is, the only part that you're really worried about here and that improvements elsewhere are more than offsetting [indiscernible] some continued headwinds there?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you're correct. I think on the E&P side of our book, that generally what we've seen is certainly some stabilization, especially with prices where they are for a barrel of oil. We have talked about in prior quarters that the oilfield services
componenttext: Yes, I think you're correct. I think on the E&P side of our book, that generally what we've seen is certainly some stabilization, especially with prices where they are for a barrel of oil. We have talked about in prior quarters that the oilfield services portion of our book will lag in terms of recovery to the E&P portion of our book. And we're seeing that. And that's the reason we're continuing to guide that between now and the end of next year. We believe our total overall losses will be somewhere in that $50 million to $75 million potential total range. We are seeing that oilfield services, we are -- here and there, this pockets in [indiscernible]. We are seeing that they are getting back to work. But again, that is, as I said, going to take, I think, the rest of '17 for that to work itself out.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then you made some comments earlier about multi-family and some of the medical care facilities pulling back from those. And just what -- give the read -- is that more about hitting concentration limits than wanting to be disciplined on that
componenttext: All right. And then you made some comments earlier about multi-family and some of the medical care facilities pulling back from those. And just what -- give the read -- is that more about hitting concentration limits than wanting to be disciplined on that front as opposed to seeing any kind of specific signs that are worrying on that kind of excluding some of the comments you made about Houston, but is in energy related locations where you're seeing -- you had some downgrades this quarter?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right. We do have a very disciplined concentration methodology. We learned a lot coming out of the last crisis. And what we learned is, diversification of our book and concentration limit management is paramount to having a good, solid, pru
componenttext: You're exactly right. We do have a very disciplined concentration methodology. We learned a lot coming out of the last crisis. And what we learned is, diversification of our book and concentration limit management is paramount to having a good, solid, prudent book. And so as we've come up with some of our concentration limits, we worked very closely with -- in particular, John Turner and his team to, again, recycle capital, but also stay well within those concentration limits. And again, that's the reason for the commentary on that and the same thing with our medical office building.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Marty Mosby of Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Marty Mosby of Vining Sparks.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I got 2 bigger kind of strategic questions. As you look at -- Barb talking about your through the cycle losses, you always spend a lot of time derisking, offloading what could be some of the more troublesome loans. Really, over time, to get the benefit fr
componenttext: I got 2 bigger kind of strategic questions. As you look at -- Barb talking about your through the cycle losses, you always spend a lot of time derisking, offloading what could be some of the more troublesome loans. Really, over time, to get the benefit from that, I think you're seeing that with lower losses now, but you should also see it with less volatility, when we get in that downdraft. I think communicating and talking about the benefits of the derisking is going to be very important for Regions. Just your thought on, as you keep saying 75 basis points, the benefits of derisking and how you could see it materialize over time.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for those comments, and you're absolutely right. We have spent a lot of time on the derisking, and part of that derisking was, as you know, in the real estate book. What we wanted to do is, as we thought about how do we rerisk our portfolio, tha
componenttext: Thank you for those comments, and you're absolutely right. We have spent a lot of time on the derisking, and part of that derisking was, as you know, in the real estate book. What we wanted to do is, as we thought about how do we rerisk our portfolio, that we do it with assets, and we do it with portfolios that are much, much less volatile and back to, again, that we do it within our concentration limits so that we don't get outside in any one area, in any one product and sticking to that discipline. The other challenge that you have when you derisk a book, and by derisking, you sell a lot of the assets, is you don't enjoy the recovery stream after. Whereas, if you instead manage a book that is prudent and less volatile where we do have losses, you do also anticipate a benefit and also have some future recovery. So there's a lot of benefits to making sure that we stay within a pretty tight state on what we're doing.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because Marty, we really are trying to make sure that we're not only diversifying, but we're remixing our loan portfolio to have it a better -- to have it be a better-performing asset through the cycle with reduced volatility, exactly to your point. We're
componenttext: Because Marty, we really are trying to make sure that we're not only diversifying, but we're remixing our loan portfolio to have it a better -- to have it be a better-performing asset through the cycle with reduced volatility, exactly to your point. We're trying to be very careful about client selectivity, trying to make sure that we understand who we're banking and how we're banking them. And we're trying to make sure that we got a full relationship with that client. And we do believe that there will be points in the cycle where we'll grow less than some peers, but we do believe that what we're doing in diversifying and managing concentration risk will, in fact, reduce the overall operating volatility of our company over a longer period of time.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have seen that, and I just think that communicating and materializing how that's going to kind of play forward is going to be important. And then David, on the extra $100 million in expense savings, you've been producing 2 to 3 percentage points of oper
componenttext: I have seen that, and I just think that communicating and materializing how that's going to kind of play forward is going to be important. And then David, on the extra $100 million in expense savings, you've been producing 2 to 3 percentage points of operating leverage. And actually, revenue growth is picking up. So I just want to go back to how you couched it in this environment. It would almost seem like things weren't improving or you weren't getting revenue growth, so you had to go and dig harder. Or you're just finding things as you've gone through, like you said, redesigning that gave you another $100 million that you can now put on the table. I think the difference between that feeling is pretty important. Is it desperation? Or is it, "No, we're just finding more things that we can do more with."

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Marty, I'm going to put it this way. We've been, really, working with a great sense of urgency on efficiency. We know it's important. But we're finding investment opportunities, and we know in this environment that we have to figure out how to self-f
componenttext: Yes, Marty, I'm going to put it this way. We've been, really, working with a great sense of urgency on efficiency. We know it's important. But we're finding investment opportunities, and we know in this environment that we have to figure out how to self-fund those investments. We have figured out how we can reduce our expenses to make those investment decisions. And those investment decisions are getting traction now. We're starting to see the benefits of some of the decisions we've made in terms of investments. You're seeing that very strongly in capital markets. But as we've gotten into this process, we've just come to the conclusion that if this environment persists, we've got to be even better. And we are finding opportunities that will allow us to extend this process further, and we believe get our company into a much better position. We do believe that operating leverage is a right metric to look at. We continue to believe we're delivering on that, but it's going to require both -- work on both revenues and expense side of the income statement. And so we can't give up on either one.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, one technical question. David, you had $13 million negative in prepayment write-offs. You're getting about half of that back in the fourth quarter. But if rates stay where they are at or at what level do you have to get to get the other $6 milli
componenttext: And then, one technical question. David, you had $13 million negative in prepayment write-offs. You're getting about half of that back in the fourth quarter. But if rates stay where they are at or at what level do you have to get to get the other $6 million back into your quarterly NII from prepayments going back to where they were in the prior quarter?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think where we are clearly is beneficial. We, obviously, have seen a lot of volatility, though, in the rates. And I think that you're right. We'll get a piece of that back naturally because of what has happened, but I think that it's going to be --
componenttext: Yes. I think where we are clearly is beneficial. We, obviously, have seen a lot of volatility, though, in the rates. And I think that you're right. We'll get a piece of that back naturally because of what has happened, but I think that it's going to be -- it's a little premature to say when we might get that other piece. And we need to see what will happen over, maybe, the next couple of quarters before we can get our -- that premium amortization down into the lower 40 range.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Erika Najarian of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Erika Najarian of Bank of America.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize in advance for prolonging the call on one more expense question, but I just wanted to make sure I understood David's response to Betsy's question correctly. The way it was framed was the core run rate for expenses was 8.80% to  8.85%, plus pot
componenttext: I apologize in advance for prolonging the call on one more expense question, but I just wanted to make sure I understood David's response to Betsy's question correctly. The way it was framed was the core run rate for expenses was 8.80% to  8.85%, plus potentially a natural growth rate of 2% to 3%. Should we then, on top of that, separately think about the $400 million of savings and that $400 million is being used to fund all those investments that you've been talking about for the past hour?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think if you look at our kind of core, that 8.8%, 8.85% is where we are, we do continue to make investments to grow our revenues. So an example would be our release we had yesterday. You'll see expenses coming through from that investment in 201
componenttext: Yes. So I think if you look at our kind of core, that 8.8%, 8.85% is where we are, we do continue to make investments to grow our revenues. So an example would be our release we had yesterday. You'll see expenses coming through from that investment in 2017 and none in '16. And so we're trying to figure out how to pay for that by having other savings. So part of that $400 million is to compensate us for that. We do have built-in natural inflation that we have, salary increases and the like, that we try to curtail by ensuring that we have the right number of people, the right number or the right kinds of people to manage our business, run our businesses. We're down some 1,200 people. We continue to challenge ourselves on that. And you see some of that manifest in the branch consolidations that we've had during the year. So the question is, "How do we keep the 8.80% and 8.85% as stable to up modestly as we can, while we're making the investments to grow revenue and having things like First Sterling with 12 months worth of expense next year and, virtually, none in '16?" Does that make sense?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does.
componenttext: It does.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Barker of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Barker of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just sort of follow-up, not to beat a dead horse, but to follow-up on expenses again. You say flat to up modestly on a yearly basis. I mean, that could be a very wide range going into the fourth quarter. Are you assuming that the run rate is going to be c
componenttext: Just sort of follow-up, not to beat a dead horse, but to follow-up on expenses again. You say flat to up modestly on a yearly basis. I mean, that could be a very wide range going into the fourth quarter. Are you assuming that the run rate is going to be closer to the 8.80% to 8.85% range coming in the fourth quarter? Or is it going to be -- could you see some volatility where that would drive that number lower?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We believe that's our core kind of run rate where we are right now for the fourth quarter is in that 8.80%, 8.85%.
componenttext: No. We believe that's our core kind of run rate where we are right now for the fourth quarter is in that 8.80%, 8.85%.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when you think about the revenue side, when you say it's going to be, on a yearly basis, up around 6% or more than 6%, it's a run rate closer to $500 million going into next quarter from 5.44%. But it seems like you have a lot of positive c
componenttext: Okay. And then when you think about the revenue side, when you say it's going to be, on a yearly basis, up around 6% or more than 6%, it's a run rate closer to $500 million going into next quarter from 5.44%. But it seems like you have a lot of positive commentary around getting the momentum on the fee income side. It seems like that number could be up a lot higher than the 6% that you're guiding to. Is there some moving parts there that may cause the number to come down considerably going into the fourth quarter?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We've had -- we grew just about every category in noninterest revenue, and we're very excited about those investments that are paying off that we've made. So I don't see that -- the 6%, reasonably left there, as our initial target at Investor Day was
componenttext: No. We've had -- we grew just about every category in noninterest revenue, and we're very excited about those investments that are paying off that we've made. So I don't see that -- the 6%, reasonably left there, as our initial target at Investor Day was 4% to 6%. We had said, we'd be in the middle. And then we said, we'd be at the upper end, and now we're giving you guidance that we'll be over 6%, but we -- that's where we stop, and we haven't -- we're letting you draw your own conclusion as to what percentage you want to use over that. But there's nothing that indicates to us that we have any type of major disruption in that trend that you're seeing on a [indiscernible] basis.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Gerard Cassidy of RBC.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions for you. David, you touched on the premium amortization and how it's going to improve, obviously, in the next quarter. And an earlier question, you talked a little bit about it, maybe, getting even better, if rates go higher. Can you q
componenttext: Couple of questions for you. David, you touched on the premium amortization and how it's going to improve, obviously, in the next quarter. And an earlier question, you talked a little bit about it, maybe, getting even better, if rates go higher. Can you quantify where rates would have to go, the 10-year government bond yield, that is, with the premium amortization would really drop significantly and would be a non-factor?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, if you took the 10-year, maybe, up closer to 2%, we might have some meaningful reduction in the premium amortization. And that's just an approximate. Because obviously, what happens with prepayments, refis and mortgages, in all ways, it totall
componenttext: So I think, if you took the 10-year, maybe, up closer to 2%, we might have some meaningful reduction in the premium amortization. And that's just an approximate. Because obviously, what happens with prepayments, refis and mortgages, in all ways, it totally correlates to the 10-year. But suffice to say, that's a pretty good proxy.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the other end, if we were to see a higher level similar to what we saw this quarter, would the 10-year need to get closer to 1.60% or below for that to reoccur?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the other end, if we were to see a higher level similar to what we saw this quarter, would the 10-year need to get closer to 1.60% or below for that to reoccur?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that we're coming off of pretty historic lows in the second quarter. And when you look at that, I've -- that's why we were able to give you, maybe, that $4 million that we don't think will repeat. But you'd have to be steady in the 1.50% for
componenttext: Yes. I think that we're coming off of pretty historic lows in the second quarter. And when you look at that, I've -- that's why we were able to give you, maybe, that $4 million that we don't think will repeat. But you'd have to be steady in the 1.50% for the quarter before it to get anywhere close to where it was.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then coming back to the capital question. Obviously, Grayson, you talked about using the capital deployment for organic growth and strategic alternatives. And David, you pointed out that you're comfortable with the CET1 ratio at 9.5%. If the NPR turns
componenttext: And then coming back to the capital question. Obviously, Grayson, you talked about using the capital deployment for organic growth and strategic alternatives. And David, you pointed out that you're comfortable with the CET1 ratio at 9.5%. If the NPR turns into an actual regulation about the qualitative portion of CCAR, you're not going to have to go through it anymore. Would you guys consider doing an accelerated share repurchase agreement in the next CCAR exam? Or a Dutch tender offer to really pull out a lot of excess capital to bring you down closer to your 9.5%, and obviously the ROU would go higher?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I'll let David add to this. But we do believe the proposed rules are constructive and give us more certainty. And we do believe that, given the risk profile of our company today, as we run through CCAR, that given the current mix that we think we'
componenttext: I mean, I'll let David add to this. But we do believe the proposed rules are constructive and give us more certainty. And we do believe that, given the risk profile of our company today, as we run through CCAR, that given the current mix that we think we're in that sort of 9.5% range, as David said. Obviously, we're trying to improve the mix of our portfolio. That will change some of our metrics if we're successful in that regard. But the rules that are proposed give us more certainty, but we still -- it's our responsibility to manage capital and do that prudently and thoughtfully. And assuming the rules get approved in somewhat similar fashion as they stand today, I think it is constructive for our bank and constructive in general for a lot of regional banks and will give us more flexibility. All that being said is, we're still some time away from those strong deliberations that go into our submission. And so it's pretty immature for us to comment on what we might or might not do in that regard, but it's a possibility.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Gerard, I would tell you, it's really important that this 9.5%, that's our number, that's our loss forecasting. That's the way we go about measuring the kind of capital we need to have. We're not interested in pushing ourselves to the point we have a q
componenttext: So Gerard, I would tell you, it's really important that this 9.5%, that's our number, that's our loss forecasting. That's the way we go about measuring the kind of capital we need to have. We're not interested in pushing ourselves to the point we have a quantitative failure and ask for a mulligan and all those kinds of things. I think it's important that we have a capital planning process with the appropriate governance, I'm talking about the board review, that helps us establish capital based on the risk in our company. Today, we think that risk would indicate 9.5% as Common Equity Tier 1 number. We are evaluating, as Grayson mentioned, how we might change that risk profile to help us to get the appropriate amount of capital that we have to keep. Now your question really is, "Fine, you're at 9.5 versus -- you're at 11%, you got to get it to 9.5%. How quick was the pace of change, assuming the NPR turns in exactly as it is?" And I think that's a great question. We're going to have a lot of thought put into that, especially after learning what we did last year from CCAR submissions. And -- but I do think, we need to be real careful about indicating this as some form of panacea. I do think that we need to be prudent, very careful on how we manage this, this capital, because we have other players. We have shareholders. We have other third parties that are looking at how we think about capital, too. So being very thoughtful about it and looking at that pace, we want to go at a pace that's fair and reasonable for all interested parties. And so a lot of work needs to be done.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vivek Juneja of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vivek Juneja of JPMorgan.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just follow-up on that capital discussion a little bit with both of you. David, to your point about, yes, it's going to take time, obviously, to go from 11% to 9.5%. And Grayson, you've been doing the bolt-on acquisitions, but they've not really us
componenttext: Let me just follow-up on that capital discussion a little bit with both of you. David, to your point about, yes, it's going to take time, obviously, to go from 11% to 9.5%. And Grayson, you've been doing the bolt-on acquisitions, but they've not really used up that much capital. And you've done a bunch of these, given how much you're generating. So as you look into '17, and I recognize you can't do this right now, but looking to '17, where does -- where do other uses of capital -- how would you prioritize them, returning more than 100% versus, say, bank acquisitions?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Vivek, you bring up a good point in terms of capital deployment. Let's go through the, how we think about it. First and foremost is organic growth. But is organic growth on things that add to the return hurdle that we're trying to get to, which is
componenttext: Yes. So Vivek, you bring up a good point in terms of capital deployment. Let's go through the, how we think about it. First and foremost is organic growth. But is organic growth on things that add to the return hurdle that we're trying to get to, which is growing to 12% to 14% return on tangible common equity. So we laid at our Investor Day. It's where we are today. We're going to update that in December. So to the extent that's not there, and we continued to generate capital that we're not utilizing, having an appropriate dividend that we have is important to us, bolt-on acquisitions that help. You're right. They don't use -- have a tendency to use up a lot of capital. And then outside of that, returning it to the shareholders and exceeding 100% payout ratio has been done. I think that's a learning that we picked up this past year, and we would consider that as well. You've mentioned bank acquisitions. When you look at valuation for us, right now, obviously, we have our CRA issue that we hope gets cleared up. But we really have to get those 2 things dealt with before we can really start looking at it. I mean, from a valuation standpoint, the math just isn't very supportive of that at this juncture.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, I think, we've been pretty clear. I mean, we're very interested in non-bank bolt-on acquisitions. We've been active in that. There will come a time when bank-related bolt-on acquisitions matter. We'll be of interest when valuations improve. And
componenttext: And David, I think, we've been pretty clear. I mean, we're very interested in non-bank bolt-on acquisitions. We've been active in that. There will come a time when bank-related bolt-on acquisitions matter. We'll be of interest when valuations improve. And I think that we look at that, and we try to understand that. I think that, right now, that's just not our primary focus for -- as David mentioned, for a couple of reasons as well as others. And so our focus on organic growth, our focus on improving the fundamentals of our company, and our focus on bolt-on acquisitions that, while they don't consume a lot of capital, they also don't add a lot of risk to our company, that it's the integration, the synergies that we create, we got the ability to do that. We're pretty good at it. We think we could continue to do that. Hopefully, over time, we can even increase the pace of this kind of activity. But it doesn't -- it's a very manageable risk profile when we execute it this way. Larger acquisitions, obviously, have a very different risk profile. And right now, we're just focused on building a very sustainable franchise value for our shareholders.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vivek, I will add one other thing. I should have mentioned this. As we do -- as we think about our 12% to 14% target in terms of return on tangible common equity, we're working on the numerator as we've just talked about for a little over an hour and a ha
componenttext: Vivek, I will add one other thing. I should have mentioned this. As we do -- as we think about our 12% to 14% target in terms of return on tangible common equity, we're working on the numerator as we've just talked about for a little over an hour and a half. But also managing the denominator in terms of our capital base and getting to our target is important in that calculation. So I think we're all -- we get the message. And it's the pace, as back to Gerard's question, the pace of how we get there, just needs to be done in a responsible manner. And we need a little bit more time to think how that might look.

componenttextpreview: I guess just kind of going back to what part of Gerard was asking about. Do you think, given the changes on the margin, a positive and expenses also a positive heading into the year future, should we be paying more attention to return on tangible equity o
componenttext: I guess just kind of going back to what part of Gerard was asking about. Do you think, given the changes on the margin, a positive and expenses also a positive heading into the year future, should we be paying more attention to return on tangible equity or return assets? Which would be more appropriate to kind of gauge the progress of Regions?

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- so we look at both. We do, when you kind of look at the -- regress the return on tangible common to stock price evaluation, it's a pretty tight correlation. So we have a tendency to focus on return on tangible common and also forces us to make
componenttext: Well, we -- so we look at both. We do, when you kind of look at the -- regress the return on tangible common to stock price evaluation, it's a pretty tight correlation. So we have a tendency to focus on return on tangible common and also forces us to make sure we have an appropriate capital base for our business model. So while ROA is important, you'll see businesses and peers that have more revenue generated from non-balance sheet, non-assets always have a higher ROA. But I think that where the rubber meets the road is really returns on the capital.

headline: Regions Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
